Headline.Para: Like chefs, financial advisers should be given their due

LeadPara.Para: Let advisers charge initial sales charge once for new money, and not when rebalancing portfolios

I have been advising clients since 1998. Having gone through multiple financial crises, the greatest being the one in 2008, I know through experience and with evidence that in order to give clients a good investment outcome, the following steps are necessary:

TailParas.Para: •Having a suitable asset allocation (different proportion of money invested in equities and bonds) based on clients' needs and ability and willingness to bear risk. This is done based on an understanding of their current financial situation and future goals as documented in their financial plan;
•Selecting suitable instruments, such as unit trusts, that are low in total expense ratio (also known as the unit trust's annual management fee) to execute the asset allocation;
•Performing regular rebalancing of the asset allocation;
•Doing regular progress checks in the context of clients' overall financial plan so as to keep them motivated to stick to the plan; and
•Performing risk/behavioural coaching so that clients can stay invested and not make rash decisions during market volatility.

All this requires quite a bit of work and competence, and most consumers do not have the knowledge, experience and tools to do it themselves. Hence, good financial advisers are engaged to perform all the above steps. And if we believe in the value of good advice, we need to compensate advisers adequately.

If we are afraid of advisers "churning" their clients' account, one way to mitigate this is to allow advisers to charge the initial sales charge only once for new money and not allow them to take any more sales charge when they rebalance clients' portfolios subsequently.

The compensation that advisers charge to perform the above is called wrap fees. In addition to wrap fees, most financial advisers also charge a front-end sales charge on the investment amount. The real purpose of this sales charge is to allow advisers who do not charge a flat fee, like Providend, to be compensated for financial/investment planning and setting up the investment accounts.

But there is a risk that some advisers might abuse it and "churn" - that is, take the sales charge each time they sell and buy unit trusts for the client - at the clients' expense. Most advisers are also paid a portion of the unit trust's annual management fee when they execute the clients' investment plan using these unit trusts.
So, in general, consumers who engage financial advisers to advise and manage their Central Provident Fund monies via the CPF Investment Scheme (CPFIS), pay the following fees:
•Front-end sales charge of up to 3 per cent of the investment amount each time clients make an investment;
•Wrap fees of up to 1 per cent per annum (pa); and
•Unit trust's annual management fee of up to 1.75 per cent pa.

While services need to be paid, all of these fees eat into returns and affect investment performance and should, as much as possible, be reduced. In the recent enhancement to the CPFIS, the following changes were made:
•Front-end sales charge has been reduced to zero per cent from Oct 1 next year; and
•Wrap fees have been reduced to 0.4 per cent pa from Oct 1 next year.
•There was no change to the unit trust's annual management fee, and fund managers can charge up to 1.75 per cent pa.
While these enhancements will ultimately reduce the initial sales charge to zero and the total recurring expense to up to 2.15 per cent pa, there are still a few problems:

•The recurring expense of up to 2.15 per cent pa is still too high. It still eats substantially into the returns of the investment portfolio. In my opinion, a fee closer to the 1 per cent pa range is more appropriate. There is a need to reduce the annual management fee to achieve that.

•While I have always been an advocate of not taking commission in giving advice, to reduce the sales charge to zero per cent may hurt good advisers, who should be paid for performing financial/investment planning for their clients.

If we are afraid of advisers "churning" their clients' account, one way to mitigate this is to allow advisers to charge the initial sales charge only once for new money, and not allow them to take any more sales charge when they rebalance clients' portfolios subsequently.

There is enough evidence to show that low-expense indexed funds or evidence-based investing funds such as those from Dimensional Fund Advisors or DFA (average management fee of 0.3 per cent) consistently perform better than expensive, actively managed unit trusts (that can charge up to 1.75 per cent pa) over the long run.
Although there are no indexed funds or DFA funds available under the CPFIS now, they could be made available in the near future.

But with wrap fees eventually reduced to 0.4 per cent pa, advisers might not be motivated to recommend these low-expense funds, as they do not get a cut of management fees. Rather, they may recommend high-expense actively managed funds instead, where they can get a cut of management fees, to the detriment of their clients. Advisers who still recommend low-cost indexed funds in the interest of their clients might be disadvantaged.
What might be more appropriate is to allow advisers to charge a wrap fee of up to, say, 0.7 per cent pa, but cut annual management fees to, say, 1 per cent pa.

If fund managers do not find this financially viable, they can always exit the CPFIS and make way for lower-expense instruments. With this change, even if advisers want to continue recommending high-expense actively managed funds, the cost is substantially reduced to below the 2 per cent pa range.

Getting a good investment outcome is like visiting a restaurant with a good chef. How good the food is, is less dependent on how expensive the ingredients are than on how good the chef is. It does not make sense to pay so much for ingredients and so little to the chef. In financial services, unit trusts are like ingredients, and financial advisers, the chefs.
Perhaps for financial advisers, the recent CPFIS enhancements is a good time for contemplation.

One may ask why wrap fees are being cut when financial advisers are required to put in so much work, while unit trusts that are partly responsible for poor investment experience can continue to charge high fees. Are we not doing the work required of us or is our work not being recognised?
•The writer is chief executive officer of Providend, a fee-only financial advisory firm specialising in retirement planning.
